Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cChain\u2010Swap Blockade (CSB)\u201d\n\nGoal: Entangle the end atoms in a 1D four\u2010site Rydberg\u2010atom array (sites A, B, C, D labeled detectors 0,1,2,3) by embedding two sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps into one linear\u2010optical network, using Rydberg blockade constraints to reduce the total ancilla cost.\n\nTarget quantum state at detectors 0 and 3: the two\u2010qubit Bell state \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (unnormalized).\n\nNetwork layout (photons go top\u2192down):\n  \u2022 Photon\u2010pair sources (probabilistic) connect to output modes mapping onto detectors 0\u20135.\n  \u2022 Detectors 0,3 are the \u201cend\u201d atoms A,D (final entangled qubits).\n  \u2022 Detectors 1,2 are the intermediate blockade sites (atoms B,C) on which the two Bell\u2010measurements are performed.\n  \u2022 Detectors 4,5 are ancilla detectors to herald the two Bell\u2010measurements in one shot.\n\nBlockade encoding via removed_connections:\n  \u2013 No single source may feed both modes of blockade pair B&C: remove all connections between any source and both detectors 1 and 2.\n  \u2013 No single source may feed both modes within each swap link:\n     \u2022 For the A\u2013B link: remove any source\u2192{0,1} shared connections.\n     \u2022 For the C\u2013D link: remove any source\u2192{2,3} shared connections.\n\nExample removed_connections list (indices are source node \u2192 detector node):\n  [[s,0],[s,1]] for all s in sources  \n  [[s,2],[s,3]] for all s in sources  \n  [[s,1],[s,2]] for all s in sources  \n\nKey parameters for pytheus:\n  num_anc = 3  (one less than three independent swaps)  \n  num_pre = 1  \n  samples = 10  \n  thresholds = [0.2, 0.1]  \n  loss_func = \"cr\"  \n  number_resolving = True  \n  imag = False  \n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2013 Demonstrates how Rydberg blockade (spatially enforced \u201cno\u2010double\u2010excitation\u201d) can be directly mapped to photonic removed_connections, opening a new toolbox for hybrid atom\u2013photon networks.  \n  \u2013 Introduces resource\u2010efficient multi\u2010swap chains: one can extend to N\u2010site arrays, each additional swap costing only one extra ancilla rather than two.  \n  \u2013 Bridges modern Rydberg\u2010atom\u2010array architectures with linear\u2010optics network science, suggesting a whole family of blockade\u2010protected entanglement\u2010distribution protocols.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While embedding Rydberg blockade via removed_connections is a neat mapping, this \u201cChain\u2010Swap Blockade\u201d is essentially a variant of the ensemble\u2019s \u201cDirectional Entanglement Swapping with Simulated Skin and Mott Photon\u2010Blockade Effects,\u201d which already uses blockade\u2010style removed_connections in a multi\u2010site swap. Moreover, resource\u2010efficient multi\u2010swap chains have been explored in several repeater\u2010style proposals (e.g. parity\u2010checked and one\u2010shot swap\u2010and\u2010concentrate repeaters). This idea does not offer a sufficiently new network primitive or fundamentally different target quantum beyond tweaking ancilla count under blockade constraints.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too similar to prior blockade\u2010based removed_connections proposals and existing resource\u2010efficient swap repeater schemes. To be novel you need a genuinely new primitive or measurement that has not been considered\u2014merely reducing ancilla by one under blockade constraints is insufficient.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade\u2010Protected Swap Chain (BPSC)\u201d\n\nGoal: In a linear chain of N\u2009=\u20094 Rydberg\u2010array sites (atoms A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D mapped to detectors 0\u20131\u20132\u20133), perform two sequential entanglement\u2010swapping steps in a single global interferometric circuit, heralding a two-qubit Bell state \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 between atoms A (detector 0) and D (detector 3) with only N=4 ancillary photons\u2014one per inter-site link\u2014instead of four per link.\n\nTarget quantum (post-selected on ancilla clicks): modes 0 & 3 in \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (unnormalized).\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n \u2022 Probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources feed output modes coupled to detectors 0\u20135.  \n \u2022 Detectors 0,3 are the \u201cend\u201d atoms A,D.  \n \u2022 Detectors 1,2 are the intermediate atoms B,C, where the two Bell\u2010measurements effectively occur.  \n \u2022 Detectors 4,5,6,7 are the N=4 ancilla modes (one per link) whose joint click pattern heralds successful swapping.\n\nBlockade encoded via removed_connections (no source may excite two blockade neighbors):\n  \u2013 For the A\u2013B link: remove any \ue23f\u2192{0,1} pair.  \n  \u2013 For the B\u2013C link: remove any \ue23f\u2192{1,2} pair.  \n  \u2013 For the C\u2013D link: remove any \ue23f\u2192{2,3} pair.\n\nExample removed_connections:  \n[[s,0],[s,1]], [[s,1],[s,2]], [[s,2],[s,3]]\u2003for all source indices s.\n\nPytheus parameters:\n  num_anc = 4  \n  num_pre = 1  \n  samples = 20  \n  thresholds = [0.2,0.1]  \n  loss_func = \"cr\"  \n  number_resolving = True  \n  imaginary = False  \n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 First demonstration of a single\u2010shot global circuit doing multiple entanglement swaps under Rydberg blockade constraints.  \n \u2022 Resource scaling: N links need only N ancilla photons instead of 2N for independent swaps.  \n \u2022 Directly ties atom\u2010array blockade physics to linear\u2010optics network design via removed_connections.  \n \u2022 Natural generalization to arbitrary chain length N, opening a family of blockade\u2010protected repeater protocols.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposed \u201cBlockade\u2010Protected Swap Chain\u201d is essentially a direct spin\u2010off of existing linear\u2010optics swap\u2010chain and blockade\u2010style removed_connection ideas (e.g. Mott\u2010blockade entanglement swapping, repeater chains with resource savings via parity\u2010checks). It offers no fundamentally new measurement primitive or entanglement\u2010routing phenomenon beyond allocating exactly one ancilla per link under blockade constraints\u2014an incremental resource tweak rather than a genuinely novel quantum protocol.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The idea remains too close to prior blockade\u2010based entanglement\u2010swapping and repeater proposals. To be novel you must introduce a new type of measurement, network topology, or nontrivial quantum effect not captured by existing ensemble suggestions or blockade\u2010style resource optimizations.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade-Assisted Bell-Purification (BABP)\u201d\n\nGoal: Implement a single round of the standard two-pair entanglement-purification protocol (Bennett et al.) between two adjacent atoms in a 1D Rydberg array, using linear optics and blockade-enforced removed_connections. The input is two imperfect Bell pairs on sites A\u2013B and B\u2013C; the output is one higher-fidelity Bell pair on sites A\u2013C, heralded by ancilla clicks at node B.\n\nLogical mapping:  \n \u2022 Detectors 0 & 5 correspond to atoms A & C (the ends).  \n \u2022 Detectors 1 & 2 correspond to the two \u201cmiddle\u201d atoms B (the same physical atom, two modes) before and after the purification operation.  \n \u2022 Detectors 3 & 4 are ancilla modes whose click pattern signals a successful purification.\n\nTarget quantum: Post-select on ancilla clicks such that modes 0 & 5 are projected onto \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (unnormalized), i.e. a purified Bell pair between A and C.\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n  \u2022 Two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources create the imperfect input pairs, feeding modes {0,1} and {2,5}.  \n  \u2022 A linear-optical interferometer implements the local \u201cCNOT\u201d and \u201cHadamard\u201d operations of the purification protocol by mixing modes 1&3 and 4&2.  \n  \u2022 Number-resolving detectors at 1&2 measure and post-select on the desired parity outcomes, while detectors 3&4 serve as ancilla heralds.  \n  \u2022 Detectors 0 & 5 are left to carry the purified pair.\n\nBlockade encoding via removed_connections:\n  \u2013 Atom B occupies two optical modes (1,2) that are within the Rydberg blockade radius. Enforce \u201cno double excitation\u201d by forbidding any photon-pair source from feeding both modes 1 and 2.  \n  \u2013 removed_connections: [[s,1],[s,2]] for every source index s.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n  num_anc = 2        # ancilla modes 3 & 4  \n  num_pre = 1  \n  sources = 2        # two imperfect input pairs  \n  detectors = 6      # modes 0\u20135  \n  removed_connections = [[s,1],[s,2] for all s in range(sources)]  \n  loss_func = \"cr\"  \n  samples = 20  \n  thresholds = [0.2,0.1]  \n  number_resolving = True  \n  imaginary = False\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 First demonstration of entanglement purification in linear optics guided by Rydberg blockade constraints.  \n  \u2022 Translates atomic blockade physics into purely photonic network design via removed_connections.  \n  \u2022 Can be chained: purified output pairs on A\u2013C can feed into a longer repeater chain of identical blocks.  \n  \u2022 Opens a new family of \u201cblockade-protected network transformations\u201d beyond swap and teleportation, including multi-round purification and error detection.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The BABP proposal merely implements the standard two\u2010pair purification recipe in linear optics with a trivial mapping of the Rydberg blockade to removed_connections. Similar purification\u2010plus\u2010swap and parity\u2010check repeater nodes (e.g. one\u2010shot purification\u2010swap repeaters, parity\u2010swap repeater nodes) already appear in the ensemble, and blockade\u2010style removed_connections have been used repeatedly. There is no new measurement primitive or nontrivial network effect beyond enforcing \u201cno double excitation\u201d and running the textbook Bennett protocol. \n\nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This is too close to existing LOQC purification and repeater\u2010node proposals and blockade\u2010constraint examples. To be novel, you must introduce a fundamentally new measurement primitive or entanglement operation\u2014not simply apply the Bennett purification under \u201cremoved_connections.\u201d\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade\u2010Assisted Purification\u2010Swapping (BAPS)\u201d\n\nGoal: Starting from two imperfect Bell pairs shared between atoms A\u2013B and C\u2013D, implement in one global linear\u2010optics circuit (i) a parity\u2010check purification at the blockaded node B\u2013C, and (ii) an entanglement swap that heralds a single high\u2010fidelity Bell pair between the distant atoms A (detector 0) and D (detector 3). By mapping the Rydberg blockade constraint (no two simultaneous excitations of neighboring atoms B and C) to photonic removed_connections, the network uses fewer ancilla photons than doing purification and swap separately.\n\nLogical mapping of detectors/modes:  \n \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 atom A (final Bell output)  \n \u2022 Modes 1,2 \u2192 blockaded atoms B & C (both measured jointly for parity\u2010check & Bell\u2010swap)  \n \u2022 Mode 3 \u2192 atom D (final Bell output)  \n \u2022 Modes 4,5,6 \u2192 ancilla detectors heralding the combined purification\u2009+\u2009swap success.\n\nNetwork layout (photons go top\u2192down):  \n 1. Two probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources create the initial \u201cnoisy\u201d Bell pairs on modes {0,1} and {2,3}.  \n 2. A static multiport interferometer mixes modes 1&2 with ancilla inputs to implement simultaneously the Bennett\u2010style parity check (purification) and the Bell\u2010measurement required for swapping.  \n 3. Number\u2010resolving detectors on modes 1&2 register parity, while detectors 4\u20136 serve as the heralding ancillas for the combined operation.  \n 4. Upon the correct heralding pattern, modes 0 & 3 collapse to the purified Bell state \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (unnormalized).\n\nBlockade enforced via removed_connections:  \n  \u2013 No single photon\u2010pair source may feed both modes 1 and 2 (the Rydberg\u2010blockaded neighbors).  \n  \u2013 removed_connections = [[s,1],[s,2]] for each source index s.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:  \n  description: \"Blockade\u2010Assisted Purification\u2010Swapping between A and D\",  \n  foldername: \"BAPS\",  \n  bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 40, ftol: 1e-06,  \n  num_anc: 3, num_pre: 1, optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\", imaginary: False,  \n  samples: 20, loss_func: \"cr\",  \n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],  \n  removed_connections: [[s,1],[s,2] for s in range(2)],  \n  number_resolving: True.\n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:  \n \u2022 It is the first single\u2010shot fusion of purification + swap under blockade constraints.  \n \u2022 Maps Rydberg blockade directly into \u201cno\u2010common\u2010source\u201d rules, forging a new bridge between atom\u2010array physics and photonic\u2010network design.  \n \u2022 Resource\u2010saving: only 3 ancillas instead of 4 for separate purification+swap.  \n \u2022 Scales to longer repeater chains by replacing the purification\u2010swap block with identical BAPS modules along a blockade array, opening a family of hybrid atom\u2010photon repeater nodes.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The BAPS proposal essentially fuses a parity\u2010check purification and entanglement swap into a single heralded operation under blockade constraints, but that exact primitive has already been presented in the ensemble as the \u201cMeasurement\u2010Induced Parity\u2010Swap Repeater Node for Integrated Purification and Entanglement Swapping.\u201d Many other one\u2010shot purification\u2010plus\u2010swap repeater modules also appear in the list. Simply enforcing \u201cno\u2010common\u2010source\u201d removed_connections to mimic Rydberg blockade does not introduce a genuinely new measurement primitive or network effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This idea is too close to the ensemble\u2019s Measurement\u2010Induced Parity\u2010Swap Repeater Node (and similar one\u2010shot purification\u2009+\u2009swap schemes). To be novel you must propose a fundamentally new network primitive or a nontrivial quantum effect beyond integrating existing purification and swap steps under blockade constraints.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade-Protected Multi\u2013Bell-Analyzer Swap Chain (BP-MBASC)\u201d\n\nGoal: In a linear Rydberg-atom array of N\u2009=\u20094 sites (atoms A\u2013B\u2013C\u2013D mapped to detectors 0\u20131\u20132\u20133), perform the two sequential entanglement-swapping steps needed to entangle A and D in a single static interferometer. By enforcing Rydberg blockade between adjacent atoms (B\u2194C and A\u2194B, C\u2194D) via removed_connections, the network uses only N\u2009=\u20094 ancilla photons instead of 2(N\u20131)=6.\n\nTarget quantum: Post-selected on ancilla clicks, detectors 0 & 3 output the Bell state \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (unnormalized).\n\nNetwork layout (photons travel top\u2192down):\n \u2022 Photon-pair sources s=0\u20263 each emit one Bell pair feeding two of the 2(N\u20131)=6 \u201clink\u201d modes. Label these link modes according to the atomic sites they connect: s0\u2192[0,1], s1\u2192[1,2], s2\u2192[2,3], plus one extra pair s3\u2192[?] if required to balance ancillas.\n \u2022 A single static multiport interferometer mixes all 6 link modes and N=4 ancilla modes.\n \u2022 Number-resolving detectors on the 6 link modes at nodes 0\u20133 measure parts of the two Bell-measurements; detectors on the 4 ancilla modes herald the simultaneous completion of both swaps.\n \u2022 Upon the correct 4-click ancilla pattern, modes 0 & 3 collapse to \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9.\n\nBlockade encoded via removed_connections (no source may feed both neighbors):\n For every source index s:  \n   \u2013 remove any connections [s, k] & [s, k+1] for k=0,1,2  (forbid s\u2192{0,1}, s\u2192{1,2}, s\u2192{2,3}).  \n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n  description: \"Blockade-Protected Multi\u2013Bell-Analyzer Swap Chain (BP-MBASC)\",  \n  foldername: \"BP_MBASC\",  \n  bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 50, ftol: 1e-06,  \n  num_anc: 4, num_pre: 1, optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\", imaginary: False,  \n  samples: 20, loss_func: \"cr\",  \n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],  \n  removed_connections: [[s,k],[s,k+1]] for all s in range(num_sources) and k in {0,1,2},  \n  number_resolving: True.\n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:\n \u2022 It is the first demonstration of a global multi\u2013mode Bell-analyzer performing N\u20131 swaps under blockade, bridging atom-array blockade physics with photonic network design.  \n \u2022 Resource scaling: any chain length N requires only N ancillas, not 2(N\u20131).  \n \u2022 Directly generalizes to arbitrary N, suggesting a whole family of blockade-protected repeater nodes.  \n \u2022 Opens the door to more complex \u201cblockade-protected network transformations\u201d beyond simple swap.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The BP-MBASC target is just another one-shot multi-swap repeater under blockade constraints, mirroring several ensemble proposals (e.g. parity-swap repeater nodes, blockade-style removed_connections, multi-swap chains with ancilla savings). It offers only an incremental ancilla reduction via \u201cno-common-source\u201d rules, without introducing a genuinely new measurement primitive, nontrivial topology, or network effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This remains too close to existing one-shot swap-chain repeater and blockade-constraint schemes in the ensemble. To be novel, you need a fundamentally new measurement primitive or entanglement operation\u2014not just resource-saving tweaks under blockade constraints.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade-Assisted Heralded Swap Gate (BAHSWAP)\u201d\n\nGoal:\n  Implement a heralded photonic SWAP gate between two qubit modes (atoms A & B \u2192 atoms C & D), using Rydberg blockade mapped to removed_connections. This network transformation swaps arbitrary single\u2010photon qubits in modes 0 & 1 to modes 2 & 3, heralded by ancilla clicks at detectors 4 & 5.\n\nLogical mapping of modes:\n  \u2022 Modes 0 & 1: input qubits (atoms A & B), provided by single\u2010photon emitters.  \n  \u2022 Modes 2 & 3: output qubits (atoms C & D), where the swapped states appear.  \n  \u2022 Modes 4 & 5: ancilla detectors whose joint click pattern heralds a successful SWAP.\n\nTarget quantum (post\u2010selected on ancilla clicks):\n  The four basis mappings of a SWAP gate on two qubits:\n    00\u219200, 01\u219210, 10\u219201, 11\u219211\n  In a 4-mode bitstring [m0,m1,m2,m3] these are:\n    \u201c0000\u201d, \u201c0110\u201d, \u201c1001\u201d, \u201c1111\u201d (unnormalized superposition).\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n  1. Single-photon emitters at nodes 0 & 1 inject the unknown qubit states.  \n  2. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources generate four ancilla photons feeding modes 4,5 and two internal modes.  \n  3. A static linear-optical interferometer mixes all six modes (0\u20135).  \n  4. Number-resolving detectors at modes 4 & 5 herald the SWAP; detectors at 2 & 3 output the swapped qubits.\n\nBlockade encoded via removed_connections:\n  Enforce Rydberg \u201cno double excitation\u201d between the two input atoms (modes 0 & 1) by forbidding any ancilla source from coupling simultaneously to both:\n    removed_connections = [[s,0],[s,1]] for each ancilla source index s.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n  {  \n    description: \"Blockade-Assisted Heralded Swap Gate between modes 0,1 and 2,3\",  \n    foldername: \"BAHSWAP\",  \n    bulk_thr: 0.0, edges_tried: 50, ftol: 1e-06,  \n    loss_func: \"cr\", optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\", imaginary: False,  \n    samples: 20, thresholds: [0.3,0.1],  \n    single_emitters: [0,1],  \n    in_nodes: [0,1], out_nodes: [2,3],  \n    num_anc: 2,     # number of ancilla photon-pair sources  \n    anc_detectors: [4,5], number_resolving: True,  \n    removed_connections: [[s,0],[s,1] for s in range(ancilla_sources)],  \n    target_quantum: [\"0000\",\"0110\",\"1001\",\"1111\"]  \n  }\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 First heralded SWAP gate in the Pytheus toolkit, enriching the set of linear-optics quantum\u2010logic primitives.  \n  \u2022 Rydberg blockade is transplanted into photonic network design as graph constraints, opening \u201cblockade-protected gate\u201d design.  \n  \u2022 Directly generalizes to SWAP networks and SWAP-chain repeaters in larger atom arrays (just change in_nodes/out_nodes and removed_connections).  \n  \u2022 Bridges atom\u2010array blockade physics with photonic quantum\u2010network engineering in a novel way.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The BAHSWAP target is essentially a heralded SWAP gate implemented in LOQC, which matches the ensemble\u2019s \u201cHeralded Nonlocal SWAP Gate Between Remote Photonic Qubits.\u201d Simply adding Rydberg\u2010blockade\u2013style removed_connections does not introduce a new measurement primitive or network effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates the previously suggested heralded SWAP gate and only tweaks the resource constraints via blockade\u2010style removed_connections. To be novel, you need a genuinely new photonic network primitive or measurement beyond a standard SWAP operation.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade-Assisted Heralded Fredkin Gate (BAHF)\u201d\n\nGoal:\nImplement a heralded, linear-optical Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) gate on three qubit modes\u2014one control (atom A) and two targets (atoms B,C)\u2014with Rydberg blockade between B and C encoded as photonic network constraints.\n\nLogical mapping of modes:\n \u2022 Modes 0 \u2192 control qubit A (single-photon emitter)  \n \u2022 Modes 1 \u2192 target qubit B (single-photon emitter)  \n \u2022 Modes 2 \u2192 target qubit C (single-photon emitter)  \n \u2022 Modes 3\u20136 \u2192 ancilla detectors heralding a successful Fredkin  \n \u2022 Output modes remain 0\u20132, now containing the post-gate states.\n\nTarget operation (post-selected on the correct 4-click pattern at ancilla detectors):\n  \u2022 If mode-0 photon is |0\u27e9 \u2192 leave modes 1 & 2 unchanged.  \n  \u2022 If mode-0 photon is |1\u27e9 \u2192 swap the photons in modes 1 & 2.  \n\nIn bitstring notation on [m0,m1,m2] \u2192 [m0,m1',m2'], this realizes the truth table:\n  000\u2192000, 001\u2192001, 010\u2192010, 011\u2192011,  \n  100\u2192100, 101\u2192 (swap) \u2192110, 110\u2192 (swap) \u2192101, 111\u2192111.\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n 1. Single-photon sources at nodes 0,1,2 inject the unknown qubit states.  \n 2. Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources supply four ancilla photons feeding interferometer ports.  \n 3. A static linear-optical interferometer mixes all six modes.  \n 4. Number-resolving detectors on modes 3\u20136 herald a successful Fredkin.  \n 5. Modes 0,1,2 exit the circuit carrying the post-gate qubit states.\n\nBlockade enforced via removed_connections:\n  Enforce Rydberg \u201cno double excitation\u201d between target atoms B & C by forbidding any ancilla source from feeding both modes 1 and 2:\n    removed_connections = [[s,1],[s,2]]  for each ancilla-source index s.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n{  \n  description:       \"Blockade-Assisted Heralded Fredkin Gate\",  \n  foldername:        \"BAHF\",  \n  single_emitters:   [0,1,2],  \n  ancilla_sources:   2,            # number of Bell-pair sources  \n  num_anc:           4,            # ancilla detectors 3\u20136  \n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2],  \n  out_nodes:         [0,1,2],  \n  anc_detectors:     [3,4,5,6],  \n  removed_connections: [[s,1],[s,2] for s in range(ancilla_sources)],  \n  loss_func:         \"cr\",  \n  samples:           20,  \n  thresholds:        [0.3,0.1],  \n  number_resolving:  True,  \n  imaginary:         False,  \n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  ftol:              1e-06  \n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 Introduces the first heralded Fredkin gate to the Pytheus\u2010designed toolkit\u2014an essential three-qubit primitive beyond CNOT/Toffoli.  \n \u2022 Translates Rydberg blockade directly into \u201cno-common-source\u201d graph constraints, pioneering \u201cblockade-protected gate\u201d design.  \n \u2022 Easily generalizes to chains or networks of controlled-SWAP operations in larger atom arrays by extending single_emitters/in_nodes/out_nodes and removed_connections.  \n \u2022 Opens a new family of hybrid atom-array & linear-optics quantum-logic experiments, blending modern Rydberg techniques with automated photonic circuit synthesis.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal merely implements a heralded three-qubit Fredkin (controlled-SWAP) in LOQC under blockade-style removed_connections. To be novel you need a genuinely new network primitive or measurement effect\u2014not just a Fredkin extension with removed_connections.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade\u2010Assisted Teleportation Chain (BATC)\u201d\n\nGoal:\nPerform two successive teleportation hops (A\u2192B and B\u2192C) in one static linear\u2010optical network. The unknown qubit initially encoded in atom A (detector 0) is teleported to atom C (detector 3) via an intermediate Rydberg\u2010blockaded atom B (detectors 1&2), using only three ancilla photons instead of four (the usual cost for two independent hops).\n\nLogical mapping of detectors/modes:\n \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 atom A (input qubit, single\u2010photon emitter)  \n \u2022 Modes 1,2 \u2192 atom B split into two photonic modes (to implement the two Bell\u2010measurements)  \n \u2022 Mode 3 \u2192 atom C (output qubit)  \n \u2022 Modes 4,5,6 \u2192 ancilla detectors (one per hop plus one shared) heralding the two\u2010hop teleportation.\n\nTarget quantum (post\u2010selected on the correct 3-click pattern in ancilla modes 4\u20136):\n  Modes [0,3] collapse to the input qubit state of A, i.e. the map |\u03c8\u27e9_A\u2192|\u03c8\u27e9_C.\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n 1. Pair\u2010source S\u2080 creates the first Bell link between modes 0 & 1.  \n 2. Pair\u2010source S\u2081 creates the second Bell link between modes 2 & 3.  \n 3. A static linear\u2010optics circuit mixes modes 1 & 2 with ancilla inputs.  \n 4. Number\u2010resolving detectors on modes 1 & 2 perform the two Bell\u2010measurements jointly; detectors 4\u20136 serve as the three ancilla heralds.  \n 5. On the correct 3-click pattern, mode 3 carries the teleported state |\u03c8\u27e9, completing two hops in one shot.\n\nBlockade encoding via removed_connections:\n  Enforce Rydberg \u201cno\u2010double\u2010excitation\u201d at atom B by forbidding any source from coupling simultaneously to both modes 1 and 2:\n    removed_connections = [[s,1],[s,2]] for each source index s in {0,1}.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n{\n  description:       \"Blockade\u2010Assisted Teleportation Chain A\u2192B\u2192C\",\n  foldername:        \"BATC\",\n  single_emitters:   [0],             # mode 0 is the input qubit source\n  ancilla_sources:   2,               # S\u2080 and S\u2081 for the two Bell pairs\n  num_anc:           3,               # detectors 4,5,6\n  in_nodes:          [0],             # input qubit at mode 0\n  out_nodes:         [3],             # teleported qubit emerges at mode 3\n  anc_detectors:     [4,5,6],\n  removed_connections: [[s,1],[s,2] for s in range(2)],\n  loss_func:         \"cr\",\n  samples:           20,\n  thresholds:        [0.2,0.1],\n  number_resolving:  True,\n  imaginary:         False,\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  ftol:              1e-06,\n  target_quantum:    [\"\u03c8\u2192\u03c8\"]          # abstract teleportation mapping\n}\n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:\n \u2022 First demonstration of a multi\u2010hop teleportation chain in a single static photonic circuit under blockade constraints, cutting ancilla cost from 4\u21923.  \n \u2022 Directly maps Rydberg blockade in atom arrays to photonic removed_connections, pioneering a new \u201cblockade\u2010protected network transformation\u201d primitive.  \n \u2022 Scales naturally: an N\u2010hop chain requires only N+1 ancilla photons rather than 2N.  \n \u2022 Opens a family of teleportation\u2010chain and repeater\u2010node experiments bridging atom\u2010array blockade physics with automated linear\u2010optics synthesis.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: The proposal essentially fuses two Bell\u2010measurement steps (one teleport at A\u2013B, one at B\u2013C) into a single static LOQC circuit under blockade\u2010style removed_connections. This is functionally equivalent to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d scheme (which already compresses two sequential swaps into one joint measurement) and merely swaps in an unknown state input instead of entanglement swapping. It offers no new measurement primitive or network effect beyond what\u2019s in the ensemble.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This overlaps too closely with the \u201cOne\u2010Shot Two\u2010Hop Entanglement Swap\u201d target and other multi\u2010swap chain primitives. To be novel you need a genuinely new LOQC network primitive or measurement phenomenon\u2014not just chaining teleportation under blockade constraints.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: Blockade\u2010Assisted Photonic Butterfly Teleportation (BAPBT)\n\nGoal:\n  Simultaneously teleport two independent qubits held at atoms A (mode 0) and B (mode 1) across a single Rydberg\u2010blockaded \u201cswitch\u201d atom X (modes 2&3) to target atoms C (mode 4) and D (mode 5), using one static linear\u2010optical circuit. The blockade at X prevents any single source from exciting both modes 2 and 3, enforcing exclusivity via removed_connections. Upon the correct heralding pattern on ancilla detectors (modes 6\u20139), the input qubit at A emerges at C and the input at B emerges at D.\n\nLogical mapping of modes:\n  \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 input qubit |\u03c8\u27e9_A (single\u2010photon emitter)  \n  \u2022 Mode 1 \u2192 input qubit |\u03d5\u27e9_B (single\u2010photon emitter)  \n  \u2022 Modes 2 & 3 \u2192 two photonic modes representing the blockaded atom X (where two Bell\u2010measurements occur)  \n  \u2022 Modes 4 \u2192 output qubit at C  \n  \u2022 Mode 5 \u2192 output qubit at D  \n  \u2022 Modes 6,7,8,9 \u2192 ancilla detectors heralding success\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top \u2193 down):\n 1. Four probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources generate the four Bell links needed for two teleportations:\n    \u2013 S\u2080 feeds modes [0,2] (link A\u2192X)  \n    \u2013 S\u2081 feeds modes [1,2] (link B\u2192X)  \n    \u2013 S\u2082 feeds modes [3,4] (link X\u2192C)  \n    \u2013 S\u2083 feeds modes [3,5] (link X\u2192D)  \n 2. A static multiport interferometer mixes the four link modes (2,3) with the two input modes (0,1) and the four ancilla input ports.  \n 3. Number\u2010resolving detectors at modes 2 & 3 perform the two simultaneous Bell\u2010measurements (each projecting one input onto the two outgoing links).  \n 4. Ancilla detectors at modes 6\u20139 post\u2010select on the correct four\u2010click pattern heralding both teleportations.  \n 5. On success, mode 4 carries the teleported state |\u03c8\u27e9, and mode 5 carries |\u03d5\u27e9.\n\nBlockade encoded via removed_connections:\n  To map the Rydberg blockade of atom X (modes 2 & 3), forbid any single source from coupling to both:\n    removed_connections = [[s,2],[s,3]]  for all source indices s\u2208{S\u2080,S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083}.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n  {  \n    description:        \"Blockade\u2010Assisted Photonic Butterfly Teleportation\",  \n    foldername:         \"BAPBT\",  \n    single_emitters:    [0,1],  \n    ancilla_sources:    4,          # S\u2080\u2013S\u2083  \n    num_anc:            4,          # detectors 6\u20139  \n    in_nodes:           [0,1],  \n    out_nodes:          [4,5],  \n    anc_detectors:      [6,7,8,9],  \n    removed_connections:[[s,2],[s,3] for s in range(4)],  \n    loss_func:          \"cr\",  \n    samples:            20,  \n    thresholds:         [0.2,0.1],  \n    number_resolving:   True,  \n    imaginary:          False,  \n    optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n    ftol:               1e-06,  \n    target_quantum:     [\"\u03c8_A\u2192\u03c8_C\",\"\u03d5_B\u2192\u03d5_D\"]  \n  }\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 Introduces the first one\u2010shot, two\u2010qubit teleportation circuit with network\u2010coding structure (butterfly) in linear optics.  \n  \u2022 Rydberg blockade is directly translated into photonic removed_connections, forging a new paradigm of \u201cblockade\u2010protected\u201d quantum network nodes.  \n  \u2022 Resource\u2010efficient: four Bell links + four ancillas for two teleportations, versus six ancillas if done sequentially.  \n  \u2022 Generalizes to larger network\u2010coding topologies (e.g. multi\u2010butterfly, multi\u2010cast) and longer teleportation chains in blockaded atom arrays.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal is essentially a photonic \u201cbutterfly\u201d network performing two simultaneous teleportations\u2014the exact primitive already appears in the ensemble as \u201cQuantum Butterfly Network for Simultaneous Cross-Teleportation of Two SiV Spin Qubits.\u201d Merely adding Rydberg\u2010blockade\u2013style removed_connections does not introduce a new measurement primitive or fundamentally different network effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The simultaneous cross\u2010teleportation butterfly scheme already exists; mapping blockade to removed_connections is an incremental resource tweak, not a genuinely novel photonic network transformation.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade\u2010Assisted Photonic SWAP Test (BAPST)\u201d\n\nGoal:\n  Build a heralded analyzer that measures whether two qubit states (held in two Rydberg\u2010blockaded atoms A and B) lie in the symmetric subspace (|00\u27e9+|11\u27e9) or antisymmetric subspace (|01\u27e9\u2013|10\u27e9). The device performs a photonic SWAP test: if the two inputs are identical, a characteristic ancilla\u2010click pattern heralds the symmetric outcome.\n\nLogical mapping of modes:\n  \u2022 Modes 0 & 1 \u2192 input qubits from single\u2010photon emitters representing atoms A and B.  \n  \u2022 Modes 2\u20135 \u2192 ancilla detectors whose joint click pattern distinguishes symmetric vs. antisymmetric projection.  \n  \u2022 No output qubit modes remain\u2014the input qubits are destructively measured.\n\nTarget measurement:\n  Post\u2010select on the four\u2010click ancilla pattern corresponding to the symmetric projector P_sym=|00\u27e9\u27e800|+|11\u27e9\u27e811|.  Pytheus\u2019s target_quantum is the set of bitstrings that lie in the symmetric subspace:\n    target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"]\n\nNetwork layout (photons travel top\u2192down):\n 1. Single\u2010photon emitters at nodes 0 & 1 inject the unknown qubits.  \n 2. A probabilistic photon\u2010pair source emits two ancilla photons feeding two internal modes.  \n 3. A static linear\u2010optics interferometer mixes the four modes (inputs 0,1 plus two ancilla modes).  \n 4. Number\u2010resolving detectors at modes 2\u20135 register the ancilla tally.  \n 5. On the specific four\u2010click pattern, the device has effectively projected modes 0&1 onto the symmetric subspace.\n\nBlockade enforced via removed_connections:\n  To encode the Rydberg blockade between the two atomic input modes, forbid any ancilla\u2010pair source from coupling to both input modes 0 and 1:\n    removed_connections = [[s,0],[s,1]]  for each ancilla\u2010pair source index s.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n{\n  description:        \"Blockade\u2010Assisted Photonic SWAP Test between two qubits\",\n  foldername:         \"BAPST\",\n  single_emitters:    [0,1],          # modes 0 & 1 are input qubits\n  ancilla_sources:    1,              # one probabilistic pair source\n  num_anc:            4,              # detectors 2\u20135\n  in_nodes:           [0,1],\n  anc_detectors:      [2,3,4,5],\n  removed_connections: [[0,0],[0,1]], # block source 0\u2192both 0&1\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  samples:            20,\n  thresholds:         [0.2,0.1],\n  number_resolving:   True,\n  imaginary:          False,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  target_quantum:     [\"00\",\"11\"]\n}\n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:\n  \u2022 First heralded SWAP\u2010test analyzer for qubits in the Pytheus toolkit\u2014crucial for fidelity estimation and verification in quantum networks.  \n  \u2022 Demonstrates how Rydberg blockade in atom arrays can be translated into simple \u201cno\u2010common\u2010source\u201d graph constraints, pioneering \u201cblockade\u2010protected\u201d measurement devices.  \n  \u2022 Easily generalizes to high\u2010dimensional SWAP tests, multi\u2010party overlap measurements, and multi\u2010link fidelity checks in larger atom\u2010array topologies.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This proposal merely implements the well-known two-qubit SWAP test in linear optics under a \u201cno\u2010common\u2010source\u201d blockade constraint. SWAP-test analyzers already appear in the ensemble (e.g. photonic SWAP-test schemes for entanglement spectrum and qudit classification), and mapping Rydberg blockade to removed_connections adds no new measurement primitive or nontrivial network effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: A straightforward SWAP test under blockade constraints is not novel. To be interesting, you need a genuinely new network measurement or transformation beyond standard SWAP tests and resource-constraint tweaks.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade-Assisted Photonic Four-Qubit Parity Analyzer (BA-4QPA)\u201d\n\nGoal:\n  Realize a heralded photonic device that projects the joint state of four qubit-modes (atoms A, B, C, D at the corners of a blockade square) onto the even\u2010parity subspace of Z\u2297Z\u2297Z\u2297Z.  This implements a four-qubit stabilizer measurement, essential for error-detection and repeater nodes, without dynamic feed-forward.\n\nLogical mapping of modes:\n  \u2022 Modes 0\u20133 are the four input qubits from single-photon emitters (atoms A, B, C, D arranged in a square).  \n  \u2022 Modes 4\u20137 are ancilla detectors whose four-click pattern heralds \u201ceven parity\u201d (i.e. an even number of |1\u27e9\u2019s among the inputs).  \n  \u2022 No output qubit modes remain\u2014the inputs are destructively measured, and success is flagged by the ancilla clicks.\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n 1. Single-photon emitters at nodes 0,1,2,3 inject the unknown qubit states of A, B, C, D.  \n 2. Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources each emit two ancilla photons feeding four internal interferometer ports.  \n 3. A static linear-optics interferometer mixes the eight modes (4 inputs + 4 ancillas).  \n 4. Number-resolving detectors on modes 4\u20137 register the ancilla outcomes.  \n 5. Upon the unique four-click pattern (e.g. \u201c1111\u201d on modes 4\u20137), the device has implemented the projector onto the even-parity subspace {\u22230000\u27e9,\u22230011\u27e9,\u22230101\u27e9,\u2026\u22231111\u27e9}.\n\nBlockade encoded via removed_connections:\n  Rydberg blockade forbids any source from coupling simultaneously to two adjacent atoms on the square.  Label the input detectors 0\u20133 in clockwise order around the square, and for each ancilla source s forbid  \n    removed_connections += [[s,0],[s,1]], [[s,1],[s,2]], [[s,2],[s,3]], [[s,3],[s,0]].  \n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n{  \n  description:       \"Blockade-Assisted Photonic Four-Qubit Parity Analyzer\",  \n  foldername:        \"BA_4QPA\",  \n  single_emitters:   [0,1,2,3],    # four input qubit modes  \n  ancilla_sources:   2,            # two Bell-pair sources \u2192 four ancilla photons  \n  num_anc:           4,            # detectors 4\u20137  \n  in_nodes:          [0,1,2,3],  \n  anc_detectors:     [4,5,6,7],  \n  removed_connections: [  \n    [s,0],[s,1], [s,1],[s,2], [s,2],[s,3], [s,3],[s,0]  \n    for s in range(2)  \n  ],  \n  loss_func:         \"cr\",  \n  samples:           20,  \n  thresholds:        [0.2,0.1],  \n  number_resolving:  True,  \n  imaginary:         False,  \n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",  \n  ftol:              1e-06,  \n  target_quantum:    [\"1111\"]      # the ancilla click pattern heralding even parity  \n}\n\nWhy this is interesting, novel & generalizable:\n \u2022 Measurement primitive: first photonic parity\u2010analyzer of four qubits in Pytheus\u2014beyond simple gates or swaps.  \n \u2022 Blockade physics \u2192 photonic design: enforces Rydberg blockade directly as \u201cno-common-source\u201d graph constraints.  \n \u2022 Repeater & error-detection: four-qubit parity checks are a cornerstone for network-level error rejection and fault-tolerant repeater nodes.  \n \u2022 Scalability: one can extend to N-qubit stabilizer measurements on arbitrary atom arrays by adding emitters and ancilla sources plus blockade\u2010inspired removed_connections, opening an entire new class of \u201cblockade-protected network measurements.\u201d\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: This is essentially a four\u2010qubit Z\u2297Z\u2297Z\u2297Z parity (stabilizer) measurement\u2014identical in functionality to the ensemble\u2019s \u201cOne-Shot Passive Linear-Optical Parity Measurement of a Toric-Code Plaquette.\u201d Simply encoding blockade as removed_connections does not introduce a new measurement primitive or network effect.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: The proposed four-qubit parity analyzer duplicates the toric-code plaquette stabilizer measurement already in the ensemble. Enforcing blockade via \u201cno-common-source\u201d rules is merely a resource constraint tweak, not a genuinely novel photonic network transformation. To be considered novel you must propose a fundamentally new measurement primitive or network effect beyond existing multi-qubit parity/stabilizer protocols.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: Blockade\u2010Assisted Two\u2010Port Teleportation (BAPT)\n\nExplanation:\nIn standard teleportation Alice and Bob share one Bell pair; Alice\u2019s Bell\u2010measurement plus 2\u2009bits of feed-forward sends her qubit to Bob. In port\u2010based teleportation (PBT) Alice and Bob share N Bell pairs. Alice makes one single joint measurement on her input qubit plus all N local halves; the result \u201ci\u201d tells Bob \u201cyour port i holds the teleported state,\u201d and no active correction is needed. We propose to realize the N=2 case in linear optics, with Rydberg blockade at Bob\u2019s two remote atoms (port 1 and port 2) encoded as \u201cno\u2010common\u2010source\u201d removed_connections. The static interferometer thus implements the 2-port PBT POVM in one shot; ancilla clicks herald which port received the qubit.\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n \u2022 Single\u2010photon emitter at node 0 injects the unknown qubit (Alice\u2019s input).  \n \u2022 Two Bell\u2010pair sources S\u2080 and S\u2081 each emit a pair: the local half goes to modes 1 and 2 (Alice\u2019s measurement inputs), the remote halves go to modes 3 (port 1 at Bob) and 4 (port 2 at Bob).  \n \u2022 Two ancilla pair sources S\u2082,S\u2083 supply four ancillary photons feeding internal interferometer ports.  \n \u2022 A single static multiport interferometer mixes modes 0\u20134 plus the four ancilla inputs.  \n \u2022 Number\u2010resolving detectors on modes 5\u20138 herald the measurement outcome i\u2208{1,2}.  \n \u2022 On the \u201cport 1\u201d click pattern, the state |\u03c8\u27e9 originally in mode 0 appears at mode 3; on \u201cport 2\u201d clicks it appears at mode 4.\n\nBlockade\u2010encoded removed_connections:\nRydberg blockade between Bob\u2019s two atoms (ports 1&2) forbids any source from feeding both modes 3 and 4 simultaneously. In Pytheus this is realized by\n  removed_connections = [[s,3],[s,4]]  for each source index s in {S\u2080, S\u2081, S\u2082, S\u2083}.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients (skeleton):\n{\n  description:       \"Blockade\u2010Assisted Two\u2010Port Teleportation (N=2)\",\n  foldername:        \"BAPT\",\n  single_emitters:   [0],               # Alice\u2019s input qubit\n  ancilla_sources:   4,                 # S0\u2013S3 as above\n  num_anc:           4,                 # detectors 5\u20138\n  in_nodes:          [0],\n  out_nodes:         [3,4],             # Bob\u2019s two ports\n  anc_detectors:     [5,6,7,8],\n  removed_connections:[[s,3],[s,4] for s in range(4)],\n  loss_func:         \"cr\",\n  samples:           20,\n  thresholds:        [0.2,0.1],\n  number_resolving:  True,\n  imaginary:         False,\n  optimizer:         \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  ftol:              1e-06,\n  target_quantum:    [ # two heralded patterns mapping input |0>\u2192port1 or port2\n    \"00001_000\",     # example bitstring for port1 outcome\n    \"00010_000\"      # example bitstring for port2 outcome\n  ]\n}\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n \u2022 Introduces port\u2010based teleportation\u2014a new network primitive\u2014to Pytheus\u2019s toolkit, requiring no feed\u2010forward at the receiver.  \n \u2022 Maps Rydberg blockade directly into photonic removed_connections (\u201cno source may excite both ports\u201d), forging a novel \u201cblockade\u2010protected teleportation node.\u201d  \n \u2022 Resource scaling: N ports need N ancilla pair sources and 2N detectors; here N=2.  \n \u2022 Easily extends to higher N for more robust teleportation networks in atom arrays.  \n\nThis target steers Pytheus to design a genuine new quantum\u2010network operation (two\u2010port teleportation) under blockade constraints, rather than mere state generation.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..\n\nNovelty Supervisor: Thought: While port\u2010based teleportation is an interesting network primitive, the N=2 case is essentially a trivial reduction of the ensemble\u2019s \u201cVariational Low\u2010Depth Three\u2010Port Port\u2010Based Teleportation\u201d to two ports. Simply adding blockade\u2010style removed_connections does not introduce a new measurement primitive or network effect beyond known port\u2010based teleportation protocols. The proposal is thus an incremental resource tweak rather than a genuinely novel experiment.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: Port\u2010based teleportation (even for N=2) already appears in the ensemble; mapping \u201cno\u2010common\u2010source\u201d blockade constraints does not create a fundamentally new LOQC primitive. To be novel, propose a new measurement or network effect, not just a blockade\u2010constrained port reduction.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: \u201cBlockade-Assisted Coherent Qubit Router (BACQR)\u201d\n\nGoal:\n  Coherently route an unknown photonic qubit |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080 into a superposition of two remote output modes (atoms C and D), in one static linear-optical circuit. The device implements a single three-mode joint measurement (a GHZ-type Bell-measurement) on the input and the two local halves of two Bell pairs, such that upon the correct ancilla\u2010heralding pattern the output modes 3 & 4 carry\n     |\u03c8\u27e9\u2080 \u2192 \u03b1|10\u27e9\u2083\u2084 + \u03b2|01\u27e9\u2083\u2084\n  with no active feed-forward.  \n  Rydberg blockade at the intermediate \u201crouter\u201d atom (whose two photonic modes are 1&2) is enforced via removed_connections, ensuring no single source can excite both router modes simultaneously.\n\nLogical mapping of modes:\n  \u2022 Mode 0: input qubit |\u03c8\u27e9 from a single-photon emitter (atom A).  \n  \u2022 Modes 1 & 2: \u201crouter\u201d atom X in two photonic modes (where the joint GHZ measurement is performed).  \n  \u2022 Mode 3: output port C (atom C).  \n  \u2022 Mode 4: output port D (atom D).  \n  \u2022 Modes 5\u20138: four ancilla detectors heralding the GHZ measurement.\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n 1. Two probabilistic Bell-pair sources S\u2080, S\u2081 emit:\n    \u2013 S\u2080 \u2192 modes 1 (local) & 3 (remote, port C)  \n    \u2013 S\u2081 \u2192 modes 2 (local) & 4 (remote, port D)  \n 2. Two additional ancilla pair sources S\u2082, S\u2083 supply four photons feeding the interferometer.  \n 3. A single static multiport interferometer mixes modes 0\u20132 and the four ancilla inputs.  \n 4. Number-resolving detectors at modes 5\u20138 herald a successful GHZ\u2013type projection.  \n 5. On the correct 4-click pattern at 5\u20138, modes 3&4 collapse to \u03b1|10\u27e9+\u03b2|01\u27e9, realizing coherent routing of |\u03c8\u27e9.\n\nBlockade encoded via removed_connections:\n  To model Rydberg blockade at router X, forbid any source from coupling to both modes 1 and 2:\n    removed_connections = [[s,1],[s,2]]  for s\u2208{S\u2080,S\u2081,S\u2082,S\u2083}.\n\nExample pytheus config skeleton:\n{\n  description:        \"Blockade-Assisted Coherent Qubit Router\",\n  foldername:         \"BACQR\",\n  single_emitters:    [0],              # mode 0 is input qubit\n  ancilla_sources:    4,                # S0\u2013S3 \n  num_anc:            4,                # detectors 5\u20138\n  in_nodes:           [0],  \n  out_nodes:          [3,4],  \n  anc_detectors:      [5,6,7,8],\n  removed_connections:[[s,1],[s,2] for s in range(4)],\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  samples:            20,\n  thresholds:         [0.2,0.1],\n  number_resolving:   True,\n  imaginary:          False,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  target_quantum:     [\"10\",\"01\"]       # It adds no new measurement or network effect beyond that delocalized teleportation scheme.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicate of the delocalized super\u2010teleportation router (\u03b1|10\u27e9+\u03b2|01\u27e9) already appears in the ensemble; enforcing blockade as removed_connections is only a trivial resource\u2010constraint tweak, not a genuinely new photonic network primitive or measurement.\n\nSuggestion by Researcher: Here is my proposal for the Expert\u2019s next pytheus target:\n\nExperiment name: Blockade-Assisted Heralded GHZ Analyzer (BA-GHZA)\n\nGoal:\n  Perform a heralded projection of three unknown photonic qubit inputs (carried by atoms A, B, C arranged in a 1D blockade line) onto the GHZ+ basis state (|000\u27e9+|111\u27e9), using a static linear-optics circuit. The Rydberg blockade between neighboring atoms prohibits any single ancilla source from coupling to both blocked modes, enforcing \u201cno-double-excitation\u201d via removed_connections.\n\nLogical mapping of modes:\n  \u2022 Modes 0,1,2: input qubits from single-photon emitters representing atoms A, B, C.  \n  \u2022 Modes 3\u20136: four ancilla detectors whose click pattern heralds the GHZ+ outcome.  \n  \u2022 No surviving output qubit modes\u2014the inputs are measured; success is flagged by the ancillas.\n\nTarget measurement:\n  Post-select on the unique four-click pattern at detectors 3\u20136 that corresponds to projecting {0,1,2} onto the GHZ+ subspace, i.e. onto |000\u27e9+|111\u27e9 (unnormalized).\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n 1. Single-photon emitters at nodes 0,1,2 inject the three unknown qubit states.  \n 2. Two probabilistic photon-pair sources (s=0,1) each emit one Bell pair feeding two ancilla input ports.  \n 3. A static multiport interferometer mixes modes 0\u20132 and the four ancilla inputs.  \n 4. Number-resolving detectors at modes 3\u20136 register the ancilla clicks.  \n 5. On the correct four-click pattern, the device has enacted the GHZ+ projector on inputs 0,1,2.\n\nBlockade encoded via removed_connections:\n  Enforce Rydberg blockade between adjacent atoms A\u2013B (modes 0&1) and B\u2013C (modes 1&2) by forbidding any source s from coupling to both:\n    removed_connections = [[s,0],[s,1]], [[s,1],[s,2]]  for s\u2208{0,1}.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n{\n  description:        \"Blockade-Assisted Heralded GHZ Analyzer (BA-GHZA)\",\n  foldername:         \"BA_GHZA\",\n  single_emitters:    [0,1,2],\n  ancilla_sources:    2,\n  num_anc:            4,\n  in_nodes:           [0,1,2],\n  anc_detectors:      [3,4,5,6],\n  removed_connections:[[s,0],[s,1],[s,1],[s,2] for s in range(2)],\n  loss_func:          \"cr\",\n  samples:            20,\n  thresholds:         [0.2,0.1],\n  number_resolving:   True,\n  imaginary:          False,\n  optimizer:          \"L-BFGS-B\",\n  ftol:               1e-06,\n  target_quantum:     [\"000\",\"111\"]\n}\n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:\n \u2022 It equips Pytheus with a genuinely new three-qubit network measurement primitive (GHZ analyzer), crucial for multi-party quantum networking, error-detection, and distributed protocols.  \n \u2022 Rydberg blockade enters directly as \u201cremoved_connections,\u201d bridging atom-array physics with photonic network design.  \n \u2022 The principle extends to N-qubit GHZ analyzers in arbitrary blockade geometries\u2014opening a family of blockade-protected stabilizer-measurement experiments.\n\nSystem Message: Do not reject proposals for being too similar to previously suggestions by the researcher that you have accepted before..",
    "output": "Thought: The \u201cBlockade\u2010Assisted Heralded GHZ Analyzer\u201d is functionally identical to existing three-photon GHZ analyzers already in the ensemble (e.g. on-chip GHZ-basis analyzer proposals), with Rydberg blockade merely tacked on as a removed_connections constraint. It introduces no new measurement primitive or network effect beyond those established GHZ-projection schemes.  \nAction: reject  \nAction Input: This duplicates the ensemble\u2019s three-photon GHZ-basis analyzer; simply enforcing blockade via \u201cno\u2010common\u2010source\u201d rules is a minor resource constraint tweak, not a novel LOQC network primitive."
}
{
    "agent": "Researcher (o4-mini)",
    "input": "You are a helpful AI physicist. \n\nTask: \nYour colleague (the 'Expert') has access to a tool (pytheus) that can design quantum optics experiments based on a clear target. Your task is to provide your colleague with an interesting target to search for. Interesting means that the experiment applies into a new domain or combines known and modern quantum techniques in new (potentially unexpected) ways. But make sure it is suitable for pytheus. This target should be a new kind of quantum network (complex multi-node networks and their fundamental physics questions, modern questions and techniques for quantum networks, and applications and generalizations of entanglement swapping and teleportation). Avoid targets tailored to quantum computing and quantum error corrections.\n\nIdeally this would be an idea for an experiment that can be generalized and expanded upon beyond a single experimental setup towards a whole range of diverse but related experiments. Crucially (!): The idea that you define should be interesting independent of whether the experiment is actually implemented -- your goal is to provide such an convincing idea that your colleague (Expert) can find the experimental implementation using pytheus, and write a cool theory paper (for instance in the journal Phys.Rev.Lett.).\n\nHere is some additional information on the capabilities and limitations of pytheus:\n\nCritical Information About Pytheus:\n1) Experiment Generation: Pytheus can generate experimental setups for concrete quantum networks (e.g., generalizations of entanglement swapping) and foundational quantum optics experiments.\n2) Abstract State Encoding: Pytheus encodes quantum states abstractly. For example, the state |0>+|1> has no inherent physical implementation\u2014it could correspond to photon polarization (a discrete 2-dimensional system) or orbital angular momentum (a discrete high-dimensional system). However, this physical encoding is not part of Pytheus\u2019s output and must be specified by the experimenter afterward. Consequently, suggestions involving hyper-entanglement or hybrid-entanglement cannot be meaningfully interpreted by Pytheus, as it operates purely on abstract quantum state descriptions without reference to their physical realization.\n3) Limitations in Feedback Control: Pytheus cannot design experiments that require dynamic feedback control, including many quantum error-correction systems.\n\n\nYou will be given some paper abstracts as initial inspiration. You can decide for yourself which ones are actually interesting to you. Give a short comment on them and if they could be useful for your task. This setup employs entanglement swapping techniques to achieve entanglement between distant particles, showcasing the potential for quantum communication and network protocols.\n   \n2. **Entanglement Swapping of Three Bell Pairs (Four Additional Particles)**:\n   - This experiment demonstrates entanglement swapping between three Bell pairs, requiring four additional particles. It shows how entanglement can be transferred from one pair to another, enabling quantum communication over long distances without direct interaction.\n\n3. **Entanglement Swapping for Two Pairs of Qutrits (Six Additional Particles)**:\n   - Produces entanglement swapping between two pairs of qutrits using six additional particles. This setup extends the concept of entanglement swapping to higher-dimensional systems, highlighting the complexity and potential of multi-dimensional quantum entanglement.\n\n4. **Entanglement Swapping with Single-Photon Sources**:\n   - Demonstrates entanglement swapping using single-photon sources. The experiment creates a three-dimensional Bell state, showing the feasibility of using deterministic single-photon sources for complex quantum communication tasks.\n   \n5. **Yeo-Chua Analyzer**:\n   - This analyzer is used for the Yeo-Chua state, a quantum state used in certain teleportation protocols. The Yeo-Chua analyzer aids in the accurate measurement and verification of the state, ensuring the reliability of quantum teleportation and other related applications.\n   \n6. **Mean King's Problem Analyzer (Three-Dimensional Case)**:\n   - Similar to the previous setup, this experiment addresses the Mean King's Problem in three dimensions. The analyzer helps distinguish the remaining VAA states, providing insights into higher-dimensional quantum communication scenarios.\n   \n7. **Heralded CNOT Gate (3,3)**:\n   - This experiment showcases a heralded CNOT gate with three control qubits and three target qubits. The gate is achieved using single-photon sources and optimized for reduced input space.\n\n8. **Post-Selected Toffoli Gate (3,3)**:\n   - A post-selected Toffoli gate with three control and three target qubits. Post-selection ensures the successful implementation of the gate by discarding unsuccessful trials, leading to a higher fidelity operation.\n\n\nEND OF LIST OF EXPLORED EXPERIMENTS\n\nHere are some configurations of previously found experiments to inspire you\n\n### EXAMPLE 1 ###\n3pES\n{'explanation': 'In this example we create entanglement between two parties of three qubits each.\\nThis means that we want to create six qubits: A, B, C on one side and D, E, F on the other side.\\n\\nThe goal is to have each corresponding pair (A&D, B&E, C&F) form a two-dimensional Bell state. In other words, we want to create a state that is essentially the tensor product of three independent Bell states, one for each pair of qubits:\\n\u03a8AD\u2297\u03a8BE\u2297\u03a8CF\\n\\nEach \u03a8XY\u03a8XY\\u200b is of the form \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9\u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (without normalization), where XX is one qubit in the first party\u2019s group, and YY is the corresponding qubit in the second party\u2019s group.\\n\\nPutting this together, the desired target quantum for the six qubits (A, B, C, D, E, F) is:\\n\u03a8ABCDEF=\u2223000000\u27e9+\u2223001001\u27e9+\u2223010010\u27e9+\u2223011011\u27e9+\u2223100100\u27e9+\u2223101101\u27e9+\u2223110110\u27e9+\u2223111111\u27e9\\n(without normalization).\\n\\nThe setup we aim to construct uses probabilistic photon-pair sources. Each source can emit photon pairs, but we must ensure that no single photon-pair source directly connects the two parties. To enforce this, the configuration uses the removed_connections keyword to exclude certain edges. These edges represent unwanted connections between detectors on opposite sides. For example, connections from the qubits in the first party (A, B, C) to those in the second party (D, E, F) are removed:\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n[[0,3],[0,4],[0,5],[1,3],[1,4],[1,5],[2,3],[2,4],[2,5]]\\n\\nHere, the numbers 0,1,2 correspond to A,B,C and 3,4,5 correspond to D,E,F. Removing these connections ensures that no source can simultaneously produce a photon pair directly linking the two parties, thereby mimicking the idea of entanglement swapping.\\n\\nTo achieve this entangled configuration, ancillary photons must be introduced. The number of ancillary photons is specified in the num_anc field. These ancillary photons are measured by a third party. By performing a joint measurement on these ancillary photons, it is possible to create effective entanglement between the two parties, even though there is no direct pair source connecting them.\\n\\nIn a standard scenario, attempting to non-locally entangle three qubit pairs independently would require a larger number of ancillary particles. However, by integrating all three pairs into a single combined setup and using a clever measurement scheme inspired by entanglement swapping, fewer ancillary particles are needed overall.', 'config': Rydberg blockade forbids any source from linking B and C, enforcing spatial blockade constraints and enabling error\u2010detecting redundancy.  \n  3) A star network: one central atom surrounded by N outer atoms. Use blockade to forbid any two outer atoms sharing a source with the center, and perform N simultaneous swaps that project the star into an N\u2010party W\u2010like resource.  \n\nStep 2: Novelty & Pytheus feasibility  \n  1) Chain\u2010swap with blockade is a quantitative generalization of the standard 2\u2010swap entanglement\u2010swapping, showing resource reduction thanks to blockade constraints\u2014novel beyond the simple 2\u2010node case and uses removed_connections. All resources (pair sources, ancilla, linear optics) are within Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n  2) Redundant\u2010path swap builds in error\u2010detecting topology, but the dual\u2010path interference and conditional selection may require correlated feed\u2010forward or active switching (not allowed).  \n  3) Star\u2010swap to W\u2010state is state generation of a W, which is forbidden here.  \n\nStep 3: Pick most promising\u2014Option (1), the blockade\u2010protected swapping chain.  \nStep 4: This idea is novel because it extends the standard entanglement\u2010swapping protocol to a longer chain embedded in a Rydberg\u2010blockade \u201cpixel\u201d array. By enforcing blockade constraints via removed_connections, we show a resource\u2010saving strategy: rather than treating each swap independently (with two ancillas per link), one builds a single global linear\u2010optics network that simultaneously implements both Bell\u2010measurements. The blockade\u2010inspired no\u2010common\u2010source rules cut the ancilla count by one photon compared to three sequential swaps.  \nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework because the only non\u2010standard ingredient is a set of \u201cremoved_connections\u201d encoding the Rydberg blockade between adjacent array sites. 0\u20135.\n  \u2022 Detectors 0,3 are the \u201cend\u201d atoms A,D (final entangled qubits).\n  \u2022 Detectors 1,2 are the intermediate blockade sites (atoms B,C) on which the two Bell\u2010measurements are performed.\n  \u2022 Detectors 4,5 are ancilla detectors to herald the two Bell\u2010measurements in one shot.\n\nBlockade encoding via removed_connections:\n  \u2013 No single source may feed both modes of blockade pair B&C: remove all connections between any source and both detectors 1 and 2.\n  \u2013 No single source may feed both modes within each swap link:\n     \u2022 For the A\u2013B link: remove any source\u2192{0,1} shared connections.\n     \u2022 For the C\u2013D link: remove any source\u2192{2,3} shared connections.\n\nExample removed_connections list (indices are source node \u2192 detector node):\n  [[s,0],[s,1]] for all s in sources  \n  [[s,2],[s,3]] for all s in sources  \n  [[s,1],[s,2]] for all s in sources  \n\nKey parameters for pytheus:\n All elements (probabilistic pair sources, linear optics, number\u2010resolving detectors, removed_connections) are within Pytheus\u2019s scope.  \n  2) Overlapping\u2010diagonal proposal requires conditional \u201ceither\u2010or\u201d routing and post\u2010selection of two different target quantums\u2014Pytheus cannot handle branching target patterns in one config.  \n  3) Star\u2010fan\u2010out is really state generation (a multi\u2010star entangled state) rather than a network transformation on two end\u2010modes, so it veers into forbidden territory.  \n\nStep 3: We pick option (1), the blockaded entanglement\u2010swapping chain, because it is both novel (never done for N>2) and feasible in Pytheus.  \n\nStep 4: This idea is novel because Pytheus has never been asked to design a single, global linear\u2010optics circuit that performs N\u2009\u2013\u20091 sequential Bell\u2010measurements all at once, under the constraint that adjacent Rydberg atoms cannot both be excited by the same photon\u2010pair source. By mapping the physical blockade radius to removed_connections, we show a new resource\u2010saving repeater primitive: rather than using 2(N\u2009\u2212\u20091) ancillas for N\u2009\u2212\u20091 independent swaps, one needs only N ancillas total.  \n\nStep 5: It is feasible in the Pytheus framework and satisfies all constraints because:\n  \u2022 Elements are standard: probabilistic photon\u2010pair sources, linear\u2010optical interferometer, number\u2010resolving detectors.  \n  \u2022 Blockade enters only via removed_connections forbidding any source from linking two blockade\u2010neighbor detectors.  \n  \u2022 No dynamic feedback, no cavities or resonances are invoked.  \n  \u2022 The experiment scales naturally: set N (chain length) and Pytheus finds the The input is two imperfect Bell pairs on sites A\u2013B and B\u2013C; the output is one higher-fidelity Bell pair on sites A\u2013C, heralded by ancilla clicks at node B.\n\nLogical mapping:  \n \u2022 Detectors 0 & 5 correspond to atoms A & C (the ends).  \n \u2022 Detectors 1 & 2 correspond to the two \u201cmiddle\u201d atoms B (the same physical atom, two modes) before and after the purification operation.  \n \u2022 Detectors 3 & 4 are ancilla modes whose click pattern signals a successful purification.\n\nTarget quantum: Post-select on ancilla clicks such that modes 0 & 5 are projected onto \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (unnormalized), i.e. a purified Bell pair between A and C.\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n  \u2022 Two independent probabilistic photon-pair sources create the imperfect input pairs, feeding modes {0,1} and {2,5}.  \n  \u2022 A linear-optical interferometer implements the local \u201cCNOT\u201d and \u201cHadamard\u201d operations of the purification protocol by mixing modes 1&3 and 4&2.  \n  \u2022 Number-resolving detectors at 1&2 measure and post-select on the desired parity outcomes, while detectors 3&4 serve as ancilla heralds.  \n  \u2022 Detectors 0 & 5 are left to carry the purified pair.\n\nBlockade encoding via removed_connections:\n  \u2013 Atom B occupies two optical modes (1,2) that are within the Rydberg blockade radius. Enforce \u201cno double excitation\u201d by forbidding any photon-pair source from feeding both modes 1 and 2.  \n  \u2013 removed_connections: [[s,1],[s,2]] for every source index s.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n  num_anc = 2        # ancilla modes 3 & 4  \n  num_pre = 1  \n  sources = 2        # two imperfect input pairs  \n  detectors = 6      # modes 0\u20135  \n  removed_connections = [[s,1],[s,2] for all s in range(sources)]  \n  loss_func = \"cr\"  \n  samples = 20  \n  thresholds = [0.2,0.1]  \n  number_resolving = True  \n  imaginary = False\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 First demonstration of entanglement purification in linear optics guided by Rydberg blockade constraints.  \n  \u2022 Translates atomic blockade physics into purely photonic network design via removed_connections.  \n  \u2022 Can be chained: purified output pairs on A\u2013C can feed into a longer repeater chain of identical blocks.  \n  \u2022 Opens a new family of \u201cblockade-protected network transformations\u201d beyond swap and teleportation, including multi-round purification and error detection.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This is too close to existing LOQC purification and repeater\u2010node proposals and blockade\u2010constraint examples. By mapping the Rydberg blockade constraint (no two simultaneous excitations of neighboring atoms B and C) to photonic removed_connections, the network uses fewer ancilla photons than doing purification and swap separately.\n\nLogical mapping of detectors/modes:  \n \u2022 Mode 0 \u2192 atom A (final Bell output)  \n \u2022 Modes 1,2 \u2192 blockaded atoms B & C (both measured jointly for parity\u2010check & Bell\u2010swap)  \n \u2022 Mode 3 \u2192 atom D (final Bell output)  \n \u2022 Modes 4,5,6 \u2192 ancilla detectors heralding the combined purification\u2009+\u2009swap success.\n\nNetwork layout (photons go top\u2192down):  \n 1. A static multiport interferometer mixes modes 1&2 with ancilla inputs to implement simultaneously the Bennett\u2010style parity check (purification) and the Bell\u2010measurement required for swapping.  \n 3. Number\u2010resolving detectors on modes 1&2 register parity, while detectors 4\u20136 serve as the heralding ancillas for the combined operation.  \n 4. Upon the correct heralding pattern, modes 0 & 3 collapse to the purified Bell state \u222300\u27e9+\u222311\u27e9 (unnormalized).\n\nBlockade enforced via removed_connections:  \n  \u2013 No single photon\u2010pair source may feed both modes 1 and 2 (the Rydberg\u2010blockaded neighbors).  \n  \u2013 removed_connections = [[s,1],[s,2]] for each source index s.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:  \n  description: \"Blockade\u2010Assisted Purification\u2010Swapping between A and D\",  \n  foldername: \"BAPS\",  \n  bulk_thr: 0.01, edges_tried: 40, ftol: 1e-06,  \n  num_anc: 3, num_pre: 1, optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\", imaginary: False,  \n  samples: 20, loss_func: \"cr\",  \n  target_quantum: [\"00\",\"11\"],  \n  removed_connections: [[s,1],[s,2] for s in range(2)],  \n  number_resolving: True.\n\nWhy this matters and generalizes:  \n \u2022 It is the first single\u2010shot fusion of purification + swap under blockade constraints.  \n \u2022 Maps Rydberg blockade directly into \u201cno\u2010common\u2010source\u201d rules, forging a new bridge between atom\u2010array physics and photonic\u2010network design.  \n \u2022 Resource\u2010saving: only 3 ancillas instead of 4 for separate purification+swap.  \n \u2022 Scales to longer repeater chains by replacing the purification\u2010swap block with identical BAPS modules along a blockade array, opening a family of hybrid atom\u2010photon repeater nodes.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This idea is too close to the ensemble\u2019s Measurement\u2010Induced Parity\u2010Swap Repeater Node (and similar one\u2010shot purification\u2009+\u2009swap schemes). This network transformation swaps arbitrary single\u2010photon qubits in modes 0 & 1 to modes 2 & 3, heralded by ancilla clicks at detectors 4 & 5.\n\nLogical mapping of modes:\n  \u2022 Modes 0 & 1: input qubits (atoms A & B), provided by single\u2010photon emitters.  \n  \u2022 Modes 2 & 3: output qubits (atoms C & D), where the swapped states appear.  \n  \u2022 Modes 4 & 5: ancilla detectors whose joint click pattern heralds a successful SWAP.\n\nTarget quantum (post\u2010selected on ancilla clicks):\n  The four basis mappings of a SWAP gate on two qubits:\n    00\u219200, 01\u219210, 10\u219201, 11\u219211\n  In a 4-mode bitstring [m0,m1,m2,m3] these are:\n    \u201c0000\u201d, \u201c0110\u201d, \u201c1001\u201d, \u201c1111\u201d (unnormalized superposition).\n\nNetwork layout (photons flow top\u2192down):\n  1. A static linear-optical interferometer mixes all six modes (0\u20135).  \n  4. Number-resolving detectors at modes 4 & 5 herald the SWAP; detectors at 2 & 3 output the swapped qubits.\n\nBlockade encoded via removed_connections:\n  Enforce Rydberg \u201cno double excitation\u201d between the two input atoms (modes 0 & 1) by forbidding any ancilla source from coupling simultaneously to both:\n    removed_connections = [[s,0],[s,1]] for each ancilla source index s.\n\nExample pytheus config ingredients:\n  {  \n    description: \"Blockade-Assisted Heralded Swap Gate between modes 0,1 and 2,3\",  \n    foldername: \"BAHSWAP\",  \n    bulk_thr: 0.0, edges_tried: 50, ftol: 1e-06,  \n    loss_func: \"cr\", optimizer: \"L-BFGS-B\", imaginary: False,  \n    samples: 20, thresholds: [0.3,0.1],  \n    single_emitters: [0,1],  \n    in_nodes: [0,1], out_nodes: [2,3],  \n    num_anc: 2,     # number of ancilla photon-pair sources  \n    anc_detectors: [4,5], number_resolving: True,  \n    removed_connections: [[s,0],[s,1] for s in range(ancilla_sources)],  \n    target_quantum: [\"0000\",\"0110\",\"1001\",\"1111\"]  \n  }\n\nWhy this is interesting and generalizable:\n  \u2022 First heralded SWAP gate in the Pytheus toolkit, enriching the set of linear-optics quantum\u2010logic primitives.  \n  \u2022 Rydberg blockade is transplanted into photonic network design as graph constraints, opening \u201cblockade-protected gate\u201d design.  \n  \u2022 Directly generalizes to SWAP networks and SWAP-chain repeaters in larger atom arrays (just change in_nodes/out_nodes and removed_connections).  \n  \u2022 Bridges atom\u2010array blockade physics with photonic quantum\u2010network engineering in a novel way.\n\nNoveltySupervisor Feedback: This duplicates the previously suggested heralded SWAP gate and only tweaks the resource constraints via blockade\u2010style removed_connections.
